Message.Msg: I’m a Systems Programmer at a local government facility they have a lot of XP machines just like what I would think most other government facilities and other business. Topic.Title: how would the "special dividend" afftect a $14 May Call option?

Message.Msg: If they go that route the stock will go up. Let's say it's $14 now and they offer a $9 SD. Don't you think that people will buy the stock to get the dividend. Of course they will, so the stock goes up. You then sell your calls. But, yes you will not get the special dividend by owning the options unless you get it thur a price increase in the options or you execute your options prior to the SD, hold the stock on the day of issue or ex dividend date. And then get the actual SD. And yes you have the problem of the stock going down after the ex dividend day. So, hold the options and when the price goes up sell the options and get your return. Don't hold for the dividend as that would not be prudent unless the stock runs up to say $20 and they offer a SD on top of that price. Then, you may want to be in stock. I would not personally do that as the options at that point has probably doubled with a pps of $29. And then the price would drop by $9 after the SD.

Topic.Title: how would the "special dividend" afftect a $14 May Call option?

Message.Msg: The option will most likely be replaced by a new option whose deliverable is "$9 in cash plus 100 shares at a strike of $5". Of course, this is never going to happen because Dell is only worth around $10/share. They're not going to take on debt to pay out a dividend with the economy as shaky as it is.

Message.Msg: CTG, Like fluteman, you came here after the rumors, after the stock price had popped 30%. You may pretend otherwise, but who are you really kidding ? I've never shorted a stock in my life. Over the recent years I have regularly traded DELL stock, usually holding for a few days to a few months at a time.Same with MSFT and CSCO. These large cap old tech type companies, during particular market conditions, are reasonably safe trading stocks. When DELL traded below 49.50 share, and even in the high $8's for a it last year, the stock offered attractive risk/reward. Where were you then ? Where was Sotheasstern Asset Management ? All the crying about a $13.65 per share offer is absurd. It's a high premum offer, especially considering DELL"s alarming negative business trends. If the current offer is not voyed YES then i expect dell stock to traded down at least as low as $10.50 per share. That is the risk anybody buying in here now, at current artificially inflated prices, should assume. Hope this helps.

Message.Title: Three possible outcomes
Message.Msg: 1. Deal goes thru for $13.65 and all this smoke and nonsense evaporate. 2. Deal falls thru, as do Icahns absurd dividend idea, and the stock goes back to $11 3. This drags on forever, but the stock never gets above $15, eventually either option 1 or 2 occur and only the lawyers make money. Dell is in a declining business, with collapsing margins. With much of their cash trapped overseas, they can barely hold the valuation they are assigned. 6 months from now, odds are this stock will either be gone at 13.65 or it will be abandoned and at $12 Icahn will be a laughing stock. You cannot just create value and hollow out Dell with a $9 special dividend unless the stock goes to $3 to do it.

Sure you can drain all the value from Dell, leverage it to infinity and pull $9 out, but to do that, the stock will go down $9 after the dividend is paid. There is no magic value here. You have one large fund that is gonna get murdered on the loss here and they are willing to try ANYTHING to get out here.

Message.Title: If I was Michael Dell, I would tell Carl Icahn
Message.Msg: If I was Michael Dell, would tell Carl Icahn "since you think, you know so much, then you make an offer to buy the company and I am dropping my offer as of right now" I think Icahn has bitten way more than he can chew and I hope everyone now has a bunch of puts on this stock because he basically ruined your nice buyout, See you guys at 8 bucks and change

The Dell Board of Director's should have pursued a strategy which would bankrupt the company ? That is ridiculous. There is absolutely no justification for borrowing money, factoring out receivables etc..... to raise money for the purpose of paying a dividend. Leveraging a company's assets only makes sense if the money is used to grow a company's business operations. To fnd its buyout offer, Mike Dell and his buyout team are borrowing to pay shareholders the $13.65 per share. This puts the risk on Mike Dell and his LBO team. If Mike Dell is able to manage the new debt, and transform the company's business lines to becoe growth lines, then certainly Mike dell and his team deserve to profit from thatw ork. but there are absolutely no guaratees that their business plans will produce profitable reults, and at the very least it will take a few years of work. Icahn's "plan" is for DELL to now borrow money to pay a dividend? That's a joke. If he wants to be taken seriously he needs to come up with the money to make his own buyout offer and then hire people to run the company. same goes for southeastern or any other disgruntled stockholder. it's put or shut up. Right now Mike Dell is the only one making an offer, and it's a generous one at that. Hope this helps.

Topic.Title: Research Firm DOWNGRADES TO SELL (EXCLUSIVE REPORT)

Message.Msg: Well, it's really now a duopoly along with WDC and quite a bit behind is Toshiba. However, it wasn't that far back that Hitachi and Samsung were competitors too. But consolidation occurred, and WDC bought Hitachi Storage (HGST) and Seagate bought Samsung disk unit. TPG tried to steal away Seagate shortly before all the disk drive merger action took place...at significantly lower price. I bought DELL a short while back at much lower prices; because I thought the PC industry could consolidate much like the disk drive players. I knew Michael Dell considered DELL, the stock, to be under valued by the market and am not surprised that he has proposed the buyout. But, what makes more sense to me is a strategic buyout by Lenovo (maybe HPQ). Consolidating the competition is the pathway to higher gross margin. I'd say Lenovo is doing much more due diligence than just kicking the tires. Although, HPQ couldn't simply stand by and allow Lenovo to overtake US and Worldwide unit sales. There could be multiple offers forthcoming. CTG

Message.Title: Focus on Ichan Analysis ($9 special dividend leveraged recapitalization vs $15 tender offer)
Message.Msg: So, there is news that Ichan made, or flirted with a $15 tender offer before demanding a leveraged recapitalization and $9/sh special dividend. Let's look at the difference in the 2 plans. $15 Tender Offer- Looks better to me than that $13.64? bid that no one but Michael could take seriously. If I had to, I'd take it, but other investors all will not let Ichan take the firm at that price. They could join him, or they could compete with him, but they won't just take the deal. In any case, $15 isn't bad and gives another %5 over today's close. To get to 15-20% the bid would have to be $16.35 - $17. Not too bad, and better than what was on the table. Leveraged recap- DELL takes money from here there, and everywhere and ships it out in the form of a $9/sh dividend. Let's assume that the stock immediately drops by $9 and it happens at tomorrow's open. What would we have? DELL would have given each of us $9 and the stock is trading at say $5 even. Now DELL still has a PE ratio, and that just went nuts. Of course, therer is more debt in the picture to drag down earnings, but really if earnings are even close to even then the PE ratio is somewhere below 4 and probably more like 2.5 or 3. The stock won't stay at that level long. I'm not sure that Ichan's $13+ post dividend valuation will be reflected in the stock immediately, but shareholders are likely left with a $9 dividend and a $8-$10 stock after a month. That's roughly $18/share Decision- The leveraged recap is obviously riskier, but it just seems to give shareholders a better deal than both the tender offer and the Dell offer. I think that shareholders should hold out for at leas $18, but nobody pays for my opinion. What do you think?

Topic.Title: could a post dividend price really last at $6?

Pollute the balance sheet with debt and there is no bottom here. Hope this helps.
